abstract.p: As mortality from critical illness continues to decrease, focus has shifted to long-term outcomes of ICU survivors. Neuromuscular weakness is a common sequela of critical illness. This weakness prolongs duration of mechanical ventilation, increases ICU and hospital length of stay, increases mortality, and can persist for years after hospital discharge. The differential diagnosis of weakness in the ICU is long, and includes critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) and critical illness myopathy (CIM). Immobilization and bed rest likely contribute to the development of CIP/CIM. Thus, early mobilization therapy has been suggested as an intervention to prevent or ameliorate ICU-acquired weakness. Early mobilization is safe, feasible, and associated with improved ICU outcomes. Emerging evidence suggests patients receiving early mobilization are more likely to be discharged home, making early mobilization therapy a potential mechanism to contain health care costs. Successful implementation of an early mobilization protocol requires changes in ICU culture and can be achieved using a structured quality improvement framework.

disp-quote.p: “The sequelae of critical illness are burdensome not only to the individual patient but also to the health care system as a whole.”

body.p: Traditionally, treatment of critically ill patients has focused on amelioration of the severe physiologic derangements and organ dysfunction that threaten survival. With recent advances in intensive care medicine, however, mortality from critical illness has decreased, shifting focus to long-term patient outcomes. The sequelae of critical illness are burdensome not only to the individual patient but also to the health care system as a whole. Neuromuscular weakness is a common sequela of critical illness, occurring in 25% to 50% of intensive care unit (ICU) patients.1,2 This weakness extends the duration of mechanical ventilation, prolongs ICU and hospital length of stay (LOS),1 and increases mortality.3 It can persist for years after hospital discharge, limiting functional status, preventing return to work, and increasing health care utilization.4,5 Although the etiology of ICU-acquired weakness (ICUAW) is multifactorial, prolonged immobilization and bed rest play an important role.

Early mobilization is a therapeutic option to reduce ICUAW by avoiding “the evil sequalae of complete bed rest.”6 Physical and occupational therapy (PT/OT), including ergometry and ambulation, are safe and feasible even in the sickest of ICU patients, including those requiring mechanical ventilation, vasopressor administration, renal replacement therapy, and left ventricular assist devices (LVADs).7-11 The advent of so-called “ambulatory” extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), which averts the need for femoral cannulation by using new dual-lumen cannulae, has even made early mobilization feasible in patients requiring extracorporeal circulatory support.12-14 Trials of early mobilization in the ICU have shown promising results.10,15-18 This article reviews the evidence behind early mobilization in the ICU and provides practical information regarding implementation of such a program.

sec.title: Epidemiology and Evaluation of Weakness in the ICU
sec.p: Neuromuscular weakness is common in the ICU. Nearly 50% of ICU patients have electrophysiologic evidence of neuromuscular weakness,1 and 25% have clinical evidence of weakness on exam.2 The differential diagnosis of weakness in the ICU is long and includes electrolyte disorders, spinal cord disease, critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP), critical illness myopathy (CIM), systemic illnesses, undiagnosed neuromuscular disease, and medication effects.19 Evaluation of the ICU patient with neuromuscular weakness should include a full history and physical, thorough review of medications, and relevant laboratory tests, such as complete blood count, electrolytes, arterial blood gas, and muscle enzymes. Autoantibodies and cerebrospinal fluid examination may also be appropriate depending on the clinical presentation. Imaging of the brain and spinal cord should be considered, especially if the physical exam reveals evidence of upper motor neuron disease, sensory level, cranial nerve involvement, or other focal findings. Electromyography/nerve conduction studies and muscle and nerve biopsies can help identify the pathology and guide prognosis.

CIP primarily affects motor and sensory axons, whereas muscles are the primary target in CIM. CIP and CIM often occur together, resulting in the clinical picture of ICUAW— symmetrical flaccid weakness of the extremities and decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes, with sparing of the cranial nerves.20 Although the pathophysiology of CIP/CIM is complex and incompletely understood, bed rest, immobility, inflammation, and cytokine production are likely involved. Indeed, systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), sepsis, and multiple organ failure have been repeatedly implicated as risk factors for the development of CIP/CIM. In fact, whereas the incidence of CIP/CIM has been estimated at 50% in general ICU populations,1 the incidence may be as high as 100% in patients with both SIRS/sepsis and multiple organ failure.21 The data on other possible risk factors, such as exposure to corticosteroids and/or neuromuscular blocking agents, have been mixed, and whether these agents predispose patients to ICUAW remains controversial.1,2,20,22 Attempts to identify interventions to prevent CIP/CIM have been disappointing. A recent Cochrane review on the topic identified only one possible preventive measure—intensive insulin therapy;23 unfortunately, this intervention is known to increase mortality in critically ill patients.24 Early mobilization therapy has emerged as a possible strategy to prevent or at least ameliorate CIP/CIM.

sec.title: Safety
sec.p: It is only rational to be concerned about the safety and feasibility of mobilizing critically ill patients. After all, such patients may have severe derangements in physiologic homeostasis, limited cardiopulmonary reserve, and decreased exercise tolerance. Furthermore, they are often attached to many lines and tubes, some of which are integral to their survival.25 However, studies have shown early mobilization in the ICU to be both safe and feasible.7-9 In these studies, early mobilization therapy was successfully administered despite perceived barriers, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressor administration, neuromuscular blocker infusion, renal replacement therapy, and delirium.8,10 Adverse event rates were low and unscheduled extubation was extremely rare. Activity sessions began as early as one day after intubation.8

sec.title: Benefits
sec.p: Prospective trials of early mobilization in the ICU have shown improved outcomes.10,15,16,18

The strongest evidence comes from 2 randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Burtin et al10 randomized 90 medical and surgical ICU patients at a single center with an ICU LOS of at least 5 days, and an expected stay of at least another 7 days, to 20 minutes per day of bedside ergometry in addition to respiratory physiotherapy and daily standardized motion of the extremities, or respiratory physiotherapy and daily standardized motion of the extremities alone.10 Functional status at hospital discharge, as measured by 6-minute walk distance, was higher in the treatment group (median 196 m vs 143 m, P < .05). Subjective feeling of well-being (as measured by the Short Form 36 Health Survey questionnaire) was also significantly higher in the treatment group. There was a trend toward a lower proportion of patients in the treatment group requiring referral to a rehabilitation center at hospital discharge (10% vs 17%), although the study was not powered to evaluate this outcome.

In another RCT, Schweickert et al18 randomized 104 sedated medical ICU patients at 2 centers who had been on mechanical ventilation for less than 72 hours and were expected to continue for at least another 24 hours to PT/OT during periods of daily sedation interruption or daily sedation interruption with therapy as ordered by the primary team. Patients in the intervention group had shorter duration of delirium (2.0 vs 4.0 days, P = .02), more ventilator-free days (23.5 vs 21.1, P = .05), and increased return to independent functional status at hospital discharge (59% vs. 35%, P = .02). Nonrandomized trials have also shown decreased ICU and hospital LOS,15,16 although these results have not been borne out in gold standard RCTs. ICU and hospital mortality have not been routinely analyzed as an endpoint; however, not receiving early mobilization therapy during an ICU stay has been identified as a risk factor for readmission or death within 1 year of hospital discharge.26

Based on the mounting evidence in favor of early mobilization, the European Respiratory Society and European Society of Intensive Care Medicine Task Force on Physiotherapy for Critically Ill Patients now clearly states that “active or passive mobilization and muscle training should be instituted early.”27

sec.title: Quality Improvement Models
sec.p: The implementation of quality improvement projects is an iterative process that requires a well thought out strategy28 and benefits from the use of a structure or framework.29 Several models exist to aid the clinician in translating evidence into practice, including the Plan–Do–Study–Act (PDSA) model and the six sigma model.30 Recently, Pronovost et al suggested a new model for “large scale knowledge translation” that can be used for any quality improvement process, including implementation of early mobilization in the ICU.29 The model is a 4-step process (Figure 1) that relies on a systems approach, the use of multidisciplinary teams, buy-in of senior management, and creation of a collaborative environment that encourages adoption of the intervention. As with the PDSA model and six sigma, this model highlights the importance of changing ICU culture. Identification of a local champion for the effort is also recommended.31 Implementation depends on “four Es”: Engaging the stakeholders, Educating stakeholders on the evidence behind the intervention, Executing the intervention, and Evaluating outcomes.29 The execution step requires creation of a detailed protocol delineating the steps of the intervention and guidelines for overcoming potential barriers. A practical guide to implementation of early mobilization in the ICU using the Pronovost et al29 model follows.

sec.title: 1. Summarize the evidence
sec.p: As discussed above, early mobilization in the ICU is safe, feasible, and effective. Randomized trials have shown it to decrease duration of mechanical ventilation, improve functional status, and increase subjective well-being.10,18 Additional studies are required to delineate the effect of early mobilization on ICU and hospital LOS, mortality, readmission rates, and health care utilization and to estimate the potential public health impact and economic implications of this intervention.

sec.title: 2. Identify barriers to implementation
sec.p: Current practice patterns may interfere with mobility.32 To identify potential barriers, one must scrutinize each step of implementation. Walking through the process with a sample patient may be helpful. Additionally, care should be taken to discuss potential barriers with all stakeholders, as perceived barriers to mobilization differ among various health care providers.33 The perceived patient-related barriers to early mobilization therapy—endotracheal tubes, central venous catheters, vasopressor requirements, renal replacement therapy, sedation, delirium, ECMO, LVADs—have been largely refuted.7-9 It is important, however, to identify not only patient-related barriers but also structure and process-related barriers. Such barriers include lack of appropriate equipment (for instance, portable mechanical ventilators for ambulating patients), insufficient staffing, cumbersome order sets, or default bed rest orders. Perceived cost of the intervention may also be viewed as a barrier; however, analyses have shown the costs of early mobilization programs may be offset by decreased ICU and hospital LOS.15,34 Existing ICU culture can be another barrier to early mobilization. Indeed, Thomsen et al35 assessed patients before and after transfer to a respiratory ICU where early activity is a priority and found that the number of patients ambulating after 48 hours in the respiratory ICU was threefold compared with pretransfer rates (P = .019). Thus, the authors concluded that the patients had been subject to “unnecessary immobilization” in ICUs where early mobilization is not embedded in the culture. Methods for overcoming these barriers will be addressed in Step 4.

sec.title: 3. Measure performance
sec.p: Data integrity in quality improvement projects is essential as clinicians, hospital leaders, and policy makers make important decisions based on the results.36 The performance measure can evaluate either process or outcome. Either way, it should be scientifically sound, accurate, and feasible.37 If possible, measures should be pilot-tested. Baseline performance must be measured prior to implementation of the intervention. Possible performance measures for early mobilization in the ICU include percentage of patients receiving PT/OT, percentage of patients ambulating at ICU or hospital discharge, 6-minute walk distance, functional status as measured by the Functional Independence Measure, and percentage of patients discharged from the hospital to home. Adverse events must also be defined and measured to ensure the safety of the program.

sec.title: 4. Ensure all patients receive the intervention
sec.p: This step involves the “four Es”: engage, educate, execute, evaluate. To ensure stakeholder buy-in, one must engage the multidisciplinary team and, armed with the evidence created in Step 1, convince them of the benefits of the intervention. Execution of the intervention requires a standardized protocol or treatment algorithm (Figure 2). Mobilization and physical activity should occur in a graded fashion, starting with passive range of motion exercises and progressing to the goal of ambulating unassisted. Cycle ergometry should be considered for patients who are unable to participate in conventional physical therapy.38,39 The clinical management algorithms developed by Hanekom et al provide guidance on choosing the appropriate modality and intensity of activity based on patients’ clinical status and exercise tolerance.40 Prespecified contraindications to initiating therapy should be defined (Table 1), but practitioners should be encouraged to consider each patient’s baseline and clinical trends. Furthermore, adverse events requiring premature cessation of therapy should be clearly defined and methods for overcoming potential barriers to early mobilization should be suggested (Table 2). Ongoing evaluation of the program allows for continuous improvement.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: As mortality from critical illness has decreased, attention has shifted to long-term outcomes of ICU survivors. Neuromuscular weakness is one of the most common and burdensome sequelae of critical illness. The differential diagnosis for weakness in the ICU is long, and includes CIP/CIM. CIP/CIM is associated with prolonged mechanical ventilation, increased ICU and hospital LOS, and increased mortality. Early mobilization therapy has been suggested for the prevention and treatment of weakness in the ICU. Early mobilization is safe, feasible, and improves outcomes. Implementation of an early mobilization program requires a structured approach and a change in ICU culture. Additional research on early mobilization is necessary to determine its public health implications, including its effect on mortality, health care utilization, and cost.
